awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Hardware-Aware AutoML Platform for Resource-Constrained Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to automate manufacturing inspection, reducing the cost of certain highly engineered projects.  This project will develop a system to automatically create machine learning models for resource-constrained industrial hardware. This project enables the fast, affordable, and easy creation of on-device artificial intelligence with significant industrial applications. This will improve robust vision-inspection tools to improve product quality. 

This project will develop an efficient solution to create advanced industrial internet of things applications that reduce network stress, minimize latency, and increase security at the edge. While the internet of things has many applications in the manufacturing industry, the vision inspection market can benefit due to its low-latency needs and the high stress it produces in the supporting infrastructure. This project is a flexible and modular hardware-aware machine learning model generation system that reduces manual efforts by automatically generating complex machine learning models for resource-constrained devices. Technical hurdles include the generation of neural networks that consider hardware speed and capacity constraints without human intervention. Technical milestones involve creating an automated model discovery platform tailored for edge devices, new resource-constrained neural architecture search algorithms, and hardware-aware model compression. This research aims to produce a prototype that domain experts with limited computer science training can use to create advanced industrial internet of things solutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Phase I primarily focused on the development of an efficient, effective, and precise defect detection mechanism suitable for resource-constrained environments like embedded systems. This process is crucial in various industrial sectors, especially manufacturing, as it facilitates the identification of rare defective areas within images, contributing significantly to quality control, increased productivity, reduced operational costs, and improved customer satisfaction. Accurate defect detection is integral to maintaining high-quality standards in the manufacturing industry, helping it stay competitive in a challenging global market. Inefficient processes can have severe repercussions, including increased production costs, resource wastage, shipment delays, reputational damage, and potential safety concerns that may lead to product recalls and legal liabilities. These factors could significantly undermine a company's financial stability and long-term sustainability in a highly competitive market.

 

To counter these challenges and bolster the defect detection process, Phase I research was heavily inclined towards discovering groundbreaking techniques for model optimization, architecture search, and dataset augmentation. The principal objective was the development of lightweight yet efficient and precise defect detection models. These models are designed to be suitable for deployment on resource-constrained edge devices, thereby enabling real-time, low-latency analysis and advancing quality control measures across a wide range of industries. The outcomes and accomplishments of Phase I have been detailed under three main Research Activities (RA): (RA#1) focused on developing an Object Detection System for Edge Devices, (RA#2) centered on enhancing Dataset Quality and Designing Efficient Architectures, and (RA#3) revolving around Successful Field Testing and Real-World Implementation.

 

In RA#1, efforts were dedicated towards developing and deploying machine learning (ML) models on edge devices specifically for real-time defect detection within the manufacturing domain. Considering the dire need for a high degree of efficiency and effectiveness in quality control processes in modern production environments, an end-to-end system was launched. This system seamlessly integrates a deep neural network (DNN) implemented on a resource-constrained platform with an array of input/output devices. The outcome was AutoEdge v1.0, a highly accurate defect detection model that offered real-time performance and seamless integration with edge devices. This novel development holds the potential to revolutionize the manufacturing sector by significantly enhancing quality control measures and overall operational efficiency.

 

For RA#2, the focus was directed towards enhancing dataset quality and designing efficient architectures for defect detection in resource-constrained environments. Challenges that defect detection commonly faces, such as high computational requirements, were addressed by giving due consideration to factors like model architecture, optimization techniques, and memory management. The neural architecture search (NAS) was utilized during this process to develop a framework that can autonomously discover lightweight and efficient models for defect detection. The development of AutoEdge v2.0 involved the use of an innovative defect generator. This generator significantly increased the training data and balanced datasets at the instance level. The implementation of this approach led to the discovery of lightweight and effective models. These models surpassed robust baselines and existing methodologies, all while utilizing significantly fewer network parameters.

 

Research Activity RA#3 aimed at demonstrating the robustness and adaptability of AutoEdge v2.0 in real-world manufacturing environments that demand accurate and efficient defect detection systems. To achieve this, comprehensive field testing and implementation of the system were conducted in collaboration with industry partners, ensuring seamless integration into their existing production and inspection processes. This collaboration allowed for system fine-tuning and necessary adjustments based on real-time feedback from on-site operators and technicians. Initial field testing took place at a manufacturer of automotive plastic parts, where AutoEdge v2.0 was employed to automate defect detection tasks such as identifying scratches, color defects, and missing layers post-production. The system exhibited impressive performance, with lab testing accuracy exceeding 99% and on-site testing accuracy reaching 97%. Moreover, AutoEdge v2.0 was capable of assessing each product in under a second, effectively meeting the manufacturer's requirements.

 

In conclusion, Research Activities throughout Phase I have brought forth promising results and substantial developments in the realm of defect detection, specifically within the manufacturing sector. The process of creating efficient, effective, and precise models for defect detection using machine learning and neural architecture search has demonstrated significant potential in improving quality control measures, optimizing production processes, and reducing operational costs. The successful field testing and implementation of the AutoEdge v2.0 system highlight its robustness and adaptability, thus indicating its vast applicability in diverse manufacturing environments. Moving forward, continuous collaboration with industry partners will aid in further refining and enhancing the defect detection system, pushing the boundaries of innovation, and contributing to the evolution of the manufacturing industry. There is a commitment to ongoing research and development to address emerging challenges and continue to provide groundbreaking solutions that deliver exceptional performance and operational excellence in the realm of defect detection.

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: Alfredo Costilla Reyes
